relationships.description: Reconciled respective tax bills to create the final tax legislation
Signed the tax reform bill into law on December 22, 2017

analysis.purpose: To summarize and analyze the key provisions of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act signed into law in December 2017
analysis.significance: Comprehensive analysis of major tax reform legislation affecting individuals, corporations, pass-through entities, and wealth transfer taxes

notable_quotes: Without much fanfare but with typical political controversy, the House and Senate successfully reconciled their respective tax bills and the new tax legislation was signed into law by President Trump on December 22, 2017.
Under the Act, there will be winners and losers on the personal income tax side. Generally, wage earners from no-tax states could see tax savings under the Act.
The transfer tax proposals in the Act extend the already limited reach of the federal estate, gift and GST taxes to even a smaller subset of only the wealthiest of taxpayers.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this tax analysis document

illegal_activity.description: Document is a professional tax analysis with no evidence of illegal activity

public_knowledge.context: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 was major legislation that received extensive media coverage and public discussion

analysis.summary: This tax bulletin provides a comprehensive analysis of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act signed into law in December 2017, detailing changes to individual taxes, corporate taxes, pass-through entity taxation, wealth transfer taxes, and various other provisions affecting taxpayers and businesses.
